elements.content: The reactions of Ln(NO3)3 (Ln = La, Er) with 1,4-phenylendiacetic acid (H2PDA) under hydrothermal conditions produce isostructural lanthanide coordination polymers with the empirical formula [Ln2(PDA)3(H2O)]·2H2O. The extended structure of [Ln2(PDA)3(H2O)]·2H2O consists of Ln-COO triple helixes cross-linked through the −CH2C6H4CH2− spacers of the PDA anions, showing 1D open channels along the crystallographic c axis that accommodate the guest and coordinated water molecules. Evacuation of [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]·2H2O at room temperature and at 200 °C, respectively, generates [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)] and [Er2(PDA)3], both of which give powder X-ray diffraction patterns consistent with that of [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]·2H2O. The porosity of [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)] and [Er2(PDA)3] is further demonstrated by their ability to adsorb water vapor to form [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]·2H2O quantitatively. Thermogravimetric analyses show that [Er2(PDA)3] remains stable up to 450 °C. The effective pore window size in [Er2(PDA)3] is estimated at 3.4 Å. Gas adsorption measurements indicate that [Er2(PDA)3] adsorbs CO2 into its pores and shows nonporous behavior toward Ar or N2. There is a general correlation between the pore size and the kinetic diameters of the adsorbates (CO2 = 3.3 Å, Ar = 3.40 Å, and N2 = 3.64 Å). That the adsorption favors CO2 over Ar is unprecedented and may arise from the combined differentiations on size and on host−guest interactions.
elements.clean_text: The reactions of Ln(NO3)3 (Ln = La, Er) with 1,4-phenylendiacetic acid (H2PDA) under hydrothermal conditions produce isostructural lanthanide coordination polymers with the empirical formula [Ln2(PDA)3(H2O)]⋅2H2O. The extended structure of [Ln2(PDA)3(H2O)]⋅2H2O consists of Ln-COO triple helixes cross-linked through the -CH2C6H4CH2- spacers of the PDA anions, showing 1D open channels along the crystallographic c axis that accommodate the guest and coordinated water molecules. Evacuation of [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]⋅2H2O at room temperature and at 200 °C, respectively, generates [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)] and [Er2(PDA)3], both of which give powder X-ray diffraction patterns consistent with that of [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]⋅2H2O. The porosity of [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)] and [Er2(PDA)3] is further demonstrated by their ability to adsorb water vapor to form [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]⋅2H2O quantitatively. Thermogravimetric analyses show that [Er2(PDA)3] remains stable up to 450 °C. The effective pore window size in [Er2(PDA)3] is estimated at 3.4 Å. Gas adsorption measurements indicate that [Er2(PDA)3] adsorbs CO2 into its pores and shows nonporous behavior toward Ar or N2. There is a general correlation between the pore size and the kinetic diameters of the adsorbates (CO2 = 3.3 Å, Ar = 3.40 Å, and N2 = 3.64 Å). That the adsorption favors CO2 over Ar is unprecedented and may arise from the combined differentiations on size and on host-guest interactions.

elements.content: In recent years, the design and synthesis of metal-organic coordination polymers have attracted considerable attention, for such supramolecular assemblies have interesting structures as well as potential applications as smart optoelectronic, magnetic, and porous materials. A porous coordination polymer possesses a metal-organic framework with open channels where the guest species can be removed and reintroduced reversibly without collapse of the framework. Metal-organic frameworks derived from porous coordination polymers are of interest as heterogeneous catalysts, sensors, and storage and separation devices.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In recent years, the design and synthesis of metal-organic coordination polymers have attracted considerable attention, for such supramolecular assemblies have interesting structures as well as potential applications as smart optoelectronic, magnetic, and porous materials. A porous coordination polymer possesses a metal-organic framework with open channels where the guest species can be removed and reintroduced reversibly without collapse of the framework. Metal-organic frameworks derived from porous coordination polymers are of interest as heterogeneous catalysts, sensors, and storage and separation devices.

elements.content: The past few years have seen impressive developments in using multitopic carboxylates as anionic ligands to support charge-neutral porous coordination networks. Besides robustness, such networks exclude uncoordinated counterions that could occupy and block the open channels. These attributes are favored for porous applications such as size- and shape-selective separations and catalysis. Thus far, the assembly of metal-carboxylate networks has centered on d-block metal ions such as Zn(II), Cu(II), and Co(II), and the analogous chemistry of the lanthanide ions is still lacking in scope, although several research groups, ours included, have reported some interesting findings. The coordination sites of such d-block metal ions are frequently occupied completely by the bridging carboxylates, leaving no accessible metal coordination sites in the network that might otherwise be utilized to carry out interesting chemistry such as catalysis. Because the lanthanide ions generally have higher coordination numbers than the d-block metal ions, incorporation of ancillary ligands (such as water molecules) into lanthanide coordination networks is made more likely. Such ancillary ligands may be removed without collapse of the lanthanide-organic framework, thereby generating porous solids with coordinatively unsaturated and Lewis-acidic lanthanide ions that have potential catalytic activity. This rationale has led us and others to seek porous lanthanide carboxylates.
elements.clean_text: The past few years have seen impressive developments in using multitopic carboxylates as anionic ligands to support charge-neutral porous coordination networks. Besides robustness, such networks exclude uncoordinated counterions that could occupy and block the open channels. These attributes are favored for porous applications such as size- and shape-selective separations and catalysis. Thus far, the assembly of metal-carboxylate networks has centered on d-block metal ions such as Zn(II), Cu(II), and Co(II), and the analogous chemistry of the lanthanide ions is still lacking in scope, although several research groups, ours included, have reported some interesting findings. The coordination sites of such d-block metal ions  are frequently occupied completely by the bridging carboxylates, leaving no accessible metal coordination sites in the network that might otherwise be utilized to carry out interesting chemistry such as catalysis. Because the lanthanide ions generally have higher coordination numbers than the d-block metal ions, incorporation of ancillary ligands (such as water molecules) into lanthanide coordination networks is made more likely. Such ancillary ligands may be removed without collapse of the lanthanide-organic framework, thereby generating porous solids with coordinatively unsaturated and Lewis-acidic lanthanide ions that have potential catalytic activity. This rationale has led us and others to seek porous lanthanide carboxylates.

elements.content: Among the reported network lanthanide carboxylates are those supported by rigid ring carboxylates such as 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate, and they have condensed structures containing no guest species. In pursuit of porous lanthanide coordination polymers with less condensed and more open frameworks, we have chosen to use ring ligands with carboxylate groups connected to more flexible carbon atoms. We have reported an erbium(III) porous network of the formula [Er(CTC)(H2O)2]·2.5H2O (CTC = cis,cis-1,3,5-cyclohexanetricarboxylate trianion), where the coordinated (ancillary) and guest water molecules are shown inside and outside of the brackets, respectively. Removal of the guest water generates the dehydrated solid [Er(CTC)(H2O)2], which, despite losing long-range order, reverts to the original crystalline phase [Er(CTC)(H2O)2]·2.5H2O upon exposure to water vapor.
elements.clean_text: Among the reported network lanthanide carboxylates are those supported by rigid ring carboxylates such as 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate, and they have condensed structures containing no guest species. In pursuit of porous lanthanide coordination polymers with less condensed and more open frameworks, we have chosen to use ring ligands with carboxylate groups connected to more flexible carbon atoms. We have reported an erbium(III) porous network of the formula [Er(CTC)(H2O)2]⋅2.5H2O (CTC = cis,cis-1,3,5-cyclohexanetricarboxylate trianion), where the coordinated (ancillary) and guest water molecules are shown inside and outside of the brackets, respectively. Removal of the guest water generates the dehydrated solid [Er(CTC)(H2O)2], which, despite losing long-range order, reverts to the original crystalline phase [Er(CTC)(H2O)2]⋅2.5H2O upon exposure to water vapor.

elements.content: In this work, we present a study of lanthanide(III) coordination polymers supported by 1,4-phenylendiacetate, a readily available ligand material that heretofore has not been utilized to support metal-organic frameworks. These isostructural lanthanide(III) carboxylates, formulated empirically as [Ln2(PDA)3(H2O)]·2H2O (Ln = La, Er; PDA = 1,4-phenylendiacetate dianion), have been synthesized through hydrothermolysis and structurally characterized via single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The erbium(III) compound [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]·2H2O has been used representatively in porosity studies, which led to the generation of well-defined porous phases [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)] and [Er2(PDA)3] that exhibit novel and significant properties previously not observed for lanthanide-organic coordination polymers or other metal-organic frameworks.
elements.clean_text: In this work, we present a study of lanthanide(III) coordination polymers supported by 1,4-phenylendiacetate, a readily available ligand material that heretofore has not been utilized to support metal-organic frameworks. These isostructural lanthanide(III) carboxylates, formulated empirically as [Ln2(PDA)3(H2O)]⋅2H2O (Ln = La, Er; PDA = 1,4-phenylendiacetate dianion), have been synthesized through hydrothermolysis and structurally characterized via single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The erbium(III) compound [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]⋅2H2O has been used representatively in porosity studies, which led to the generation of well-defined porous phases [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)] and [Er2(PDA)3] that exhibit novel and significant properties previously not observed for lanthanide-organic coordination polymers or other metal-organic frameworks.

elements.content: Materials and Methods. Lanthanum(III) and erbium(III) nitrates and 1,4-phenylendiacetic acid (H2PDA) were purchased from commercial suppliers and were used without further purification. Infrared spectra (IR) were recorded on a Thermo-Nicolet Avatar 360 FTIR spectrometer from neat solids placed on the diamond window of a horizontal attenuated total reflectance accessory. Thermogravimetric (TG) analyses were performed under N2 using a TA 2050 system. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) data were recorded on a Rigaku D/M-2200T automated diffractometer. Simulated XRD patterns were calculated with the SHELXTL-XPOW program using the single-crystal data. Microelemental analyses were performed by Atlantic Microlab in Norcross, GA. The adsorption isotherms were measured at 273 K for CO2 and at 77 K for N2 and Ar, using an Autosorb-1 system of Quantachrome and ultrapure gases (99.999%).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 Materials and Methods. Lanthanum(III) and erbium(III) nitrates and 1,4-phenylendiacetic acid (H2PDA) were purchased from commercial suppliers and were used without further purification. Infrared spectra (IR) were recorded on a Thermo-Nicolet Avatar 360 FTIR spectrometer from neat solids placed on the diamond window of a horizontal attenuated total reflectance accessory. Thermogravimetric (TG) analyses were performed under N2 using a TA 2050 system. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) data were recorded on a Rigaku D/M-2200T automated diffractometer. Simulated XRD patterns were calculated with the SHELXTL-XPOW program using the single-crystal data. Microelemental analyses were performed by Atlantic Microlab in Norcross, GA. The adsorption isotherms were measured at 273 K for CO2 and at 77 K for N2 and Ar, using an Autosorb-1 system of Quantachrome and ultrapure gases (99.999%).

elements.content: Synthesis of [Ln 2 (PDA) 3 (H 2 O)]·2H 2 O (Ln = La, Er). Identical procedures were employed to prepare the two compounds; that for the erbium compound is described here in detail. A mixture of Er(NO3)3·5H2O (0.353 g, 0.80 mmol) and H2PDA (0.095 g, 0.49 mmol) was placed in a Teflon-lined Parr bomb containing 10 mL of deionized water and 1 mL of ethanol. The bomb was sealed, heated at 170 °C for 3 days, and allowed to cool to room temperature. Pink crystals were isolated by decanting the supernatant, washed thoroughly with deionized water, ethanol, and acetone, and air-dried to give 0.124 g of product (78%). Main IR absorption bands (cm-1):  3422 (w, br), 1529 (s, br), 1396 (s), 1278 (m), 718 (m). Anal. Calcd for C30H30O15Er2 = [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]·2H2O:  C, 37.34; H, 3.13. Found:  C, 37.31; H, 3.00. The phase purity of the bulk products was checked by comparing its observed and simulated XRD patterns.
elements.clean_text: Synthesis of [Ln  2  (PDA)  3  (H  2  O)]⋅2H  2  O (Ln = La, Er). Identical procedures were employed to prepare the two compounds; that for the erbium compound is described here in detail. A mixture of Er(NO3)3⋅5H2O (0.353 g, 0.80 mmol) and H2PDA (0.095 g, 0.49 mmol) was placed in a Teflon-lined Parr bomb containing 10 mL of deionized water and 1 mL of ethanol. The bomb was sealed, heated at 170 °C for 3 days, and allowed to cool to room temperature. Pink crystals were isolated by decanting the supernatant, washed thoroughly with deionized water, ethanol, and acetone, and air-dried to give 0.124 g of product (78%). Main IR absorption bands (cm-1): 3422 (w, br), 1529 (s, br), 1396 (s), 1278 (m), 718 (m). Anal. Calcd for C30H30O15Er2 = [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]⋅2H2O: C, 37.34; H, 3.13. Found: C, 37.31; H, 3.00. The phase purity of the bulk products was checked by comparing its observed and simulated XRD patterns.

elements.content: The lanthanum compound was prepared analogously using Ln(NO3)3. Main IR absorption bands (cm-1):  3438 (w, br), 1523 (s, br), 1380 (s), 1270 (m), 711 (m). The phase purity of the bulk products was checked by comparing its observed and simulated XRD patterns.
elements.clean_text: The lanthanum compound was prepared analogously using Ln(NO3)3. Main IR absorption bands (cm-1): 3438 (w, br), 1523 (s, br), 1380 (s), 1270 (m), 711 (m). The phase purity of the bulk products was checked by comparing its observed and simulated XRD patterns.

elements.content: Generation of [Er 2 (PDA) 3 (H 2 O)] and [Er 2 (PDA) 3 ]. A freshly isolated sample of [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]·2H2O (218 mg) was evacuated under 2 × 10-3 Torr at room temperature for 4 h. The measured weight loss (8.0 mg) was equivalent to the loss of two water molecules per formula unit (calcd 8.1 mg). Another sample of [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]·2H2O (468 mg) was evacuated under 2 × 10-3 Torr at 200 °C for 4 h and allowed to cool to room temperature. The measured weight loss (26.0 mg) was equivalent to the loss of three water molecules per formula unit (calcd 26.2 mg). The XRD patterns of [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)] and [Er2(PDA)3] are both consistent with that of [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]·2H2O. Exposure of [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)] and [Er2(PDA)3] to water vapor for 12 h resulted in weight gains corresponding to two and three water molecules per formula unit, respectively. The dehydration and rehydration processes were reversible.
elements.clean_text: Generation of [Er  2  (PDA)  3  (H  2  O)] and [Er  2  (PDA)  3  ]. A freshly isolated sample of [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]⋅2H2O (218 mg) was evacuated under 2 × 10-3 Torr at room temperature for 4 h. The measured weight loss (8.0 mg) was equivalent to the loss of two water molecules per formula unit (calcd 8.1 mg). Another sample of [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]⋅2H2O (468 mg) was evacuated under 2 × 10-3 Torr at 200 °C for 4 h and allowed to cool to room temperature. The measured weight loss (26.0 mg) was equivalent to the loss of three water molecules per formula unit (calcd 26.2 mg). The XRD patterns of [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)] and [Er2(PDA)3] are both consistent with that of [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]⋅2H2O. Exposure of [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)] and [Er2(PDA)3] to water vapor for 12 h resulted in weight gains corresponding to two and three water molecules per formula unit, respectively. The dehydration and rehydration processes were reversible.

elements.content: Thermal Analyses. A TG analysis performed on a sample of [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]·2H2O showed continuous weight loss (5.47%) between 50 and 140 °C, which corresponded to the loss of three water molecules per formula unit (calcd 5.59%). No further weight loss was observed until it reached 450 °C, at which the decomposition of [Er2(PDA)3] occurred, as indicated by a significant weight loss (57.1%). No attempt was made to identify the products of decomposition. A TG analysis of [La2(PDA)3(H2O)]·2H2O gave similar results.
elements.clean_text: Thermal Analyses. A TG analysis performed on a sample of [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]⋅2H2O showed continuous weight loss (5.47%) between 50 and 140 °C, which corresponded to the loss of three water molecules per formula unit (calcd 5.59%). No further weight loss was observed until it reached 450 °C, at which the decomposition of [Er2(PDA)3] occurred, as indicated by a significant weight loss (57.1%). No attempt was made to identify the products of decomposition. A TG analysis of [La2(PDA)3(H2O)]⋅2H2O gave similar results.

elements.content: X-ray Crystallography. Several crystals of each compound were indexed on a Bruker SMART CCD diffractometer using 40 frames with an exposure time of 20 s per frame. One crystal of each compound with good reflection quality was chosen for data collection. The exposure time was 20 s for each frame. The reflections were collected in the hemisphere of the reciprocal lattice of the monoclinic cell to ensure enough redundancy. An empirical absorption correction using the program SADABS was applied to all observed reflections. The structure was solved with direct methods using the SHELXTL program. Full matrix least-squares refinement on F  2 was carried out using the SHELXTL program. The unit cell information and refinement details are summarized in Table .
elements.clean_text: X-ray Crystallography. Several crystals of each compound were indexed on a Bruker SMART CCD diffractometer using 40 frames with an exposure time of 20 s per frame. One crystal of each compound with good reflection quality was chosen for data collection. The exposure time was 20 s for each frame. The reflections were collected in the hemisphere of the reciprocal lattice of the monoclinic cell to ensure enough redundancy. An empirical absorption correction using the program SADABS was applied to all observed reflections. The structure was solved with direct methods using the SHELXTL program. Full matrix least-squares refinement on F 2 was carried out using the SHELXTL program. The unit cell information and refinement details are summarized in Table .

Syntheses and X-ray Structures. Coordination polymers of the formula [Ln2(PDA)3(H2O)]·2H2O (Ln = La, Er; PDA = 1,4-phenylendiacetate dianion) were synthesized from the hydrothermal reactions of lanthanide(III) nitrates with 1,4-phenylendiacetic acid (H2PDA). These crystalline solids are insoluble in water or common organic solvents such as acetone andethanol. The IR spectra of the two compounds are similar, each showing strong absorption bands between 1350 and 1550 cm-1 that are diagnostic of coordinated carboxylate groups. The absence of the strong carboxyl absorption band at 1698 cm-1 for H2PDA indicates complete deprotonation of H2PDA. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses revealed that the two compounds are isostructural, and the structure of [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]·2H2O is described here representatively. The numbers of crystallographically independent Er(III) cations and PDA anions are two and four, respectively. Figure shows the metal coordination environment in [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]·2H2O. While both Er(III) ions are coordinated by eight oxygen atoms from six COO- groups of different PDA anions, only one (Er1) is additionally coordinated by a water molecule. The coordination geometry around Er1 may be described as a tricapped trigonal prism, with O21, O41, O23, O32#1, O11, and O13#1 filling the vertexes and O12, O24, and OW1 capping the rectangular faces. The coordination geometry for eight-coordinate Er2 is close to that of a dodecahedron. The Er−O (carboxylate) bond distances range from 2.239(7) to 2.677(8) Å, and that of the Er−O (aqua) bond is 2.367(7) Å, all of which are within the range of those observed for other eight- or nine-coordinate Er(III) complexes with oxygen donor ligands. Selected bond distances and angles are presented in Table .
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

 Syntheses and X-ray Structures. Coordination polymers of the formula [Ln2(PDA)3(H2O)]⋅2H2O (Ln = La, Er; PDA = 1,4-phenylendiacetate dianion) were synthesized from the hydrothermal reactions of lanthanide(III) nitrates with 1,4-phenylendiacetic acid (H2PDA). These crystalline solids are insoluble in water or common organic solvents such as acetone  andethanol. The IR spectra of the two compounds are similar, each showing strong absorption bands between 1350 and 1550 cm-1 that are diagnostic of coordinated carboxylate groups. The absence of the strong carboxyl absorption band at 1698 cm-1 for H2PDA indicates complete deprotonation of H2PDA. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses revealed that the two compounds are isostructural, and the structure of [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]⋅2H2O is described here representatively. The numbers of crystallographically independent Er(III) cations and PDA anions are two and four, respectively. Figure  shows the metal coordination environment in [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]⋅2H2O. While both Er(III) ions are coordinated by eight oxygen atoms from six COO- groups of different PDA anions, only one (Er1) is additionally coordinated by a water molecule. The coordination geometry around Er1 may be described as a tricapped trigonal prism, with O21, O41, O23, O32#1, O11, and O13#1 filling the vertexes and O12, O24, and OW1 capping the rectangular faces. The coordination geometry for eight-coordinate Er2 is close to that of a dodecahedron. The Er-O (carboxylate) bond distances range from 2.239(7) to 2.677(8) Å, and that of the Er-O (aqua) bond is 2.367(7) Å, all of which are within the range of those observed for other eight- or nine-coordinate Er(III) complexes with oxygen donor ligands. Selected bond distances and angles are presented in Table .

In the polymeric structure of [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]·2H2O, the Er(III) ions are interconnected through COO- groups, forming what may be viewed as an Er-COO triple helix that extends in the crystallographic c direction (Figure ). The two types of Er(III) ions, which adopt an extended zigzag orientation, act as nodes alternately, and three COO- groups bridge two adjacent Er(III) ions in bis-monodentate syn−syn (e.g., −O21−C28−O22−) and tridentate (e.g., −O11−C18−O12−) bonding modes. These one-dimensional (1D) infinite helixes may be viewed as supramolecular SBUs (secondary building blocks) that are further cross-linked via the −CH2C6H4CH2− spacers of the PDA anions (Chart ). Viewed along the crystallographic c axis, the resulting 3D network of [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]·2H2O is reminiscent of the shape of a compressed honeycomb, showing 1D open channels (Figure ). The guest water molecules suspend in the channels, and the coordinated water molecules point away from the Er-PDA framework and into the channels.
elements.clean_text: In the polymeric structure of [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]⋅2H2O, the Er(III) ions are interconnected through COO- groups, forming what may be viewed as an Er-COO triple helix that extends in the crystallographic c direction (Figure ). The two types of Er(III) ions, which adopt an extended zigzag orientation, act as nodes alternately, and three COO- groups bridge two adjacent Er(III) ions in bis-monodentate syn-syn (e.g., -O21-C28-O22-) and tridentate (e.g., -O11-C18-O12-) bonding modes. These one-dimensional (1D) infinite helixes may be viewed as supramolecular SBUs (secondary building blocks) that are further cross-linked via the -CH2C6H4CH2- spacers of the PDA anions (Chart ). Viewed along the crystallographic c axis, the resulting 3D network of [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]⋅2H2O is reminiscent of the shape of a compressed honeycomb, showing 1D open channels (Figure ). The guest water molecules suspend in the channels, and the coordinated water molecules point away from the Er-PDA framework and into the channels.

elements.content: Fragment of the Er-COO helix. The aqua ligand on Er1 is omitted.
elements.clean_text: 2  Fragment of the Er-COO helix. The aqua ligand on Er1 is omitted.

elements.content: Representation of the extended structure of [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]·2H2O. Color scheme:  Er, blue; O, red; C, gray; H, white. H atoms in H2O molecules are omitted.
elements.clean_text: 3  Representation of the extended structure of [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]⋅2H2O. Color scheme: Er, blue; O, red; C, gray; H, white. H atoms in H2O molecules are omitted.

elements.content: Dehydration and Porosity. The openness of the channels makes it possible to remove the guest and coordinated water molecules from [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]·2H2O. Evacuation of [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]·2H2O at room temperature removed the guest water molecules quantitatively, affording the dehydrated solid [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)], whose XRD pattern is consistent with that of [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]·2H2O (Figure ). This indicates preservation of the framework and retention of the crystalline order upon removal of the guest species; the latter property has had only a few precedents in lanthanide coordination polymers. Further removal of the coordinated water ligand could maximize pore volume and achieve a porous metal-organic framework with coordinatively unsaturated and Lewis-acidic lanthanide ions. Assisted by TG measurements, a preparative-scale sample of [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]·2H2O was heated at 200 °C under vacuum, causing the loss of three water molecules per formula unit. The resulting solid [Er2(PDA)3] retains the framework and crystallinity observed in the original compound [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]·2H2O, as supported by the consistent XRD patterns of the two substances (Figure ). Previously, there have been reports of lanthanide-organic frameworks derived from removing ancillary ligands. Such materials typically show loss of crystalline order and/or collapse or distortion of framework, as compared with the original coordination polymers. [Er2(PDA)3] represents a rare example of a crystalline and structurally well-defined lanthanide-organic framework with ancillary ligands totally removed and Lewis-acidic metal sites opened up. Furthermore, according to TG analyses, [Er2(PDA)3] remains stable up to 450 °C at which it begins to decompose. The structural stability of [Er2(PDA)3] could be in part due to eight-coordination around each Er(III) ion. This observation dovetails with an earlier comment that while removal of both coordinated water molecules from [Er(CTC)(H2O)2] leads to framework collapse, the Er-CTC framework is retained in [Er(CTC)(H2O)] where each Er(III) ion is still eight-coordinate. One additional reason could be that the carboxylate groups in [Er2(PDA)3] all act in the bridging mode and most of them also act in the chelating mode. The porous nature of [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)] and [Er2(PDA)3] was further demonstrated by their ability to adsorb water vapor to form [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]·2H2O. The dehydration and rehydration processes were reversible.

This indicates preservation of the framework and retention of the crystalline order upon removal of the guest species; the latter property has had only a few precedents in lanthanide coordination polymers. Further removal of the coordinated water ligand could maximize pore  volume and achieve a porous metal-organic framework with coordinatively unsaturated and Lewis-acidic lanthanide ions. Assisted by TG measurements, a preparative-scale sample of [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]⋅2H2O was heated at 200 °C under vacuum, causing the loss of three water molecules per formula unit. The resulting solid [Er2(PDA)3] retains the framework and crystallinity observed in the original compound [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]⋅2H2O, as supported by the consistent XRD patterns of the two substances (Figure ). Previously, there have been reports of lanthanide-organic frameworks derived from removing ancillary ligands. Such materials typically show loss of crystalline order and/or collapse or distortion of framework, as compared with the original coordination polymers. [Er2(PDA)3] represents a rare example of a crystalline and structurally well-defined lanthanide-organic framework with ancillary ligands totally removed and Lewis-acidic metal sites opened up. Furthermore, according to TG analyses, [Er2(PDA)3] remains stable up to 450 °C at which it begins to decompose. The structural stability of [Er2(PDA)3] could be in part due to eight-coordination around each Er(III) ion. This observation dovetails with an earlier comment that while removal of both coordinated water molecules from [Er(CTC)(H2O)2] leads to framework collapse, the Er-CTC framework is retained in [Er(CTC)(H2O)] where each Er(III) ion is still eight-coordinate. One additional reason could be that the carboxylate groups in [Er2(PDA)3] all act in the bridging mode and most of them also act in the chelating mode.  The porous nature of [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)] and [Er2(PDA)3] was further demonstrated by their ability to adsorb water vapor to form [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]⋅2H2O. The dehydration and rehydration processes were reversible.

elements.content: XRD patterns:  [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]·2H2O (top), [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)] (middle), and [Er2(PDA)3] (bottom).

elements.content: The well-defined structure of [Er2(PDA)3] allows us to estimate its pore window size by computationally removing the guest and coordinated water molecules from the crystal structure of [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]·2H2O. While a ball-and-stick model reveals three localized openings on the cross section of the open channel, a space-filling model suggests that only the middle aperture, which shows an approximately circular contour, has an effective dimension (ca. 3.4 Å) that is large enough for uptake of adsorbates (Figure ).
elements.clean_text: The well-defined structure of [Er2(PDA)3] allows us to estimate its pore window size by computationally removing the guest and coordinated water molecules from the crystal structure of [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]⋅2H2O. While a ball-and-stick model reveals three localized openings on the cross section of the open channel, a space-filling model suggests that only the middle aperture, which shows an approximately circular contour, has an effective dimension (ca. 3.4 Å) that is large enough for uptake of adsorbates (Figure ).

elements.content: Cross section of the open channel in [Er(PDA)1.5]:  ball-and-stick model (top), space-filling model (bottom). Color scheme:  Er, blue; O, red; C, gray; H, white.
elements.clean_text: 5  Cross section of the open channel in [Er(PDA)1.5]: ball-and-stick model (top), space-filling model (bottom). Color scheme: Er, blue; O, red; C, gray; H, white.

elements.content: Adsorption Phenomena. There have appeared in the literature reports of adsorption behavior of porous metal-organic frameworks derived from coordination polymers. On the basis of careful studies, Rosseinsky et al. recently have made two observations on some metal-organic framework adsorbents:  (1) the adsorbents may not be well-defined structurally, and (2) the actual porous structures responsible for uptaking the adsorbates may result from the adsorbents undergoing guest-directed framework transformations. Such adsorbent characteristics are different from those of zeolites to which the adsorbents are frequently compared, for zeolites have known framework structures that are largely insensitive to uptake of guest species. Thus, there are many open questions with respect to the adsorption behavior of metal-organic frameworks. The well-defined porous framework [Er2(PDA)3] makes a good system for adsorption studies. Samples of [Er(PDA)1.5] were subjected to gas adsorption measurements using CO2, Ar, and N2, whose kinetic diameters are known to be 3.3, 3.40, and 3.64 Å, respectively. It was observed that [Er2(PDA)3] adsorbs CO2 into its pores and shows nonporous behavior toward Ar or N2 (Figure ), which indicates a general correlation between the pore size and the kinetic diameters of the adsorbates. N2 cannot be adsorbed apparently because its kinetic diameter is greater than the effective pore window size. [Er2(PDA)3] favors CO2 over Ar in porous adsorption, despite the subtle difference (0.1 Å) in the kinetic diameters of the two gases. Such selectivity is unprecedented for porous metal-organic frameworks and may arise from the combined differentiations on size and on host−guest interactions. The framework host, which contains Er(III) ions, polar groups, and π-electrons, gives rise to an electric field that induces a dipole in CO2. Besides such dipole−induced-dipole interactions, the quadrupole moment of CO2 would interact with the electric field gradient, making a further contribution to the potential energy of adsorption. In addition, there may be some donor−acceptor affinity between the Lewis-acidic Er(III) ions and the CO2 molecules. In the case of Ar, the only major interactions are dipole−induced-dipole forces.
elements.clean_text: Adsorption Phenomena. There have appeared in the literature reports of adsorption behavior of porous metal-organic frameworks derived from coordination polymers. On the basis of careful studies, Rosseinsky et al. recently have made two observations on some metal-organic framework adsorbents: (1) the adsorbents may not be well-defined structurally, and (2) the actual porous structures responsible for uptaking the adsorbates may result from the adsorbents undergoing guest-directed framework transformations. Such adsorbent characteristics are different from those of zeolites to which the adsorbents are frequently compared, for zeolites have known framework structures that are largely insensitive to uptake of guest species. Thus, there are many open questions with respect to the adsorption behavior of metal-organic frameworks. The well-defined porous framework [Er2(PDA)3] makes a good system for adsorption studies. Samples of [Er(PDA)1.5] were subjected to gas adsorption measurements using CO2, Ar, and N2, whose kinetic diameters are known to be 3.3, 3.40, and 3.64 Å, respectively. It was observed that [Er2(PDA)3] adsorbs CO2 into its pores and shows nonporous behavior toward Ar or N2 (Figure ), which indicates a general correlation between the pore size and the kinetic diameters of the adsorbates. N2 cannot be adsorbed apparently because its kinetic diameter is greater than the effective pore window size. [Er2(PDA)3] favors CO2 over Ar in porous adsorption, despite the subtle difference (0.1 Å) in the kinetic diameters of the two gases. Such selectivity is unprecedented for porous metal-organic frameworks and may arise from the combined differentiations on size and on host-guest interactions. The framework host, which contains Er(III) ions, polar groups, and π-electrons, gives rise to an electric field that induces a dipole in CO2. Besides such dipole-induced-dipole interactions, the quadrupole moment of CO2 would interact with the electric field gradient, making a further contribution to the potential energy of adsorption. In addition, there may be some donor-acceptor affinity between the Lewis-acidic Er(III) ions and the CO2 molecules. In the case of Ar, the only major interactions are dipole-induced-dipole forces.

elements.content: Adsorption isotherms of CO2, N2, and Ar. ◆ and ◇ represent adsorption and desorption of CO2, respectively. Saturation vapor pressures:  P o(CO2) = 2.7 × 104 Torr (273 K), P o(Ar) = 200 Torr (77 K), and P o(N2) = 760 Torr (77 K).
elements.clean_text: 6  Adsorption isotherms of CO2, N2, and Ar. ◆ and ◇ represent adsorption and desorption of CO2, respectively. Saturation vapor pressures: P o(CO2) = 2.7 × 104 Torr (273 K), P o(Ar) = 200 Torr (77 K), and P o(N2) = 760 Torr (77 K).

elements.content: The steep rise in the adsorption branch of CO2 was observed at extremely low pressures relative to the saturation vapor pressure of CO2, and this high initial uptake indicates the presence of intrinsic micropores in [Er2(PDA)3]. Calculations based on the Dubinin−Radushkevitch (DR) equation gave a pore volume of [Er2(PDA)3] (0.027 mL/g), as well as an isosteric heat of adsorption of CO2 at 273 K (30.1 kJ/mol). The relatively small pore volume can be understood with reference to the extended structure of [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]·2H2O that has no additional open channels along the a and b axes. The heat of adsorption is somewhat larger than that (20 kJ/mol) determined for CO2 in silicalite-I, probably because of the comparatively stronger host−guest interactions as described above. However, the heat of adsorption is still far smaller than those typical of chemical adsorption. For example, the heats of chemisorption of CO in Co and of CO2 in Ni are 176 and 184 kJ/mol, respectively. Thus, the nature of the [Er2(PDA)3]−CO2 interaction is mainly physisorption without significant chemical association. Another interesting feature of the CO2 isotherm is the hysteresis loop between the adsorption and desorption branches, which makes the isotherm different from types I−V in the IUPAC classification scheme. The mechanism for hysteresis in the adsorption/desorption isotherms of metal-organic frameworks is not well understood currently; however, guest-directed framework rearrangements have been proposed for some labile metal-polypyridine networks. It is unlikely that this mechanism operates in the hysteresis described here, for [Er2(PDA)3] has a stable framework. Most likely, the hysteresis results from the hindered diffusion of CO2 molecules in the pores of [Er2(PDA)3], for the kinetic diameter of CO2 is extremely close to the effective pore dimension.
elements.clean_text: The steep rise in the adsorption branch of CO2 was observed at extremely low pressures relative to the saturation vapor pressure of CO2, and this high initial uptake indicates the presence of intrinsic micropores in [Er2(PDA)3]. Calculations based on the Dubinin-Radushkevitch (DR) equation gave a pore volume of [Er2(PDA)3] (0.027 mL/g), as well as an isosteric heat of adsorption of CO2 at 273 K (30.1 kJ/mol). The relatively small pore volume can be understood with reference to the extended structure of [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]⋅2H2O that has no additional open channels along the a and b axes. The heat of adsorption is somewhat larger than that (20 kJ/mol) determined for CO2 in silicalite-I, probably because of the  comparatively stronger host-guest interactions as described above. However, the heat of adsorption is still far smaller than those typical of chemical adsorption. For example, the heats of chemisorption of CO in Co and of CO2 in Ni are 176 and 184 kJ/mol, respectively. Thus, the nature of the [Er2(PDA)3]-CO2 interaction is mainly physisorption without significant chemical association. Another interesting feature of the CO2 isotherm is the hysteresis loop between the adsorption and desorption branches, which makes the isotherm different from types I-V in the IUPAC classification scheme. The mechanism for hysteresis in the adsorption/desorption isotherms of metal-organic frameworks is not well understood currently; however, guest-directed framework rearrangements have been proposed for some labile metal-polypyridine networks. It is unlikely that this mechanism operates in the hysteresis described here, for [Er2(PDA)3] has a stable framework. Most likely, the hysteresis results from the hindered diffusion of CO2 molecules in the pores of [Er2(PDA)3], for the kinetic diameter of CO2 is extremely close to the effective pore dimension.

elements.content: We have synthesized novel isostructural lanthanide coordination polymers of the formula [Ln2(PDA)3(H2O)]·2H2O. We have used [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]·2H2O representatively to investigate the porous behavior of such compounds. Both the guest and the coordinated water molecules can be removed from the open channels of [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]·2H2O, yielding [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)] and [Er2(PDA)3], respectively. Both of these porous phases maintain the framework and crystalline order found in the original compound [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]·2H2O, as shown by XRD analyses. The framework polymer [Er2(PDA)3] is highly robust, remaining stable up to 450 °C. [Er2(PDA)3] adsorbs CO2, but not Ar or N2, apparently because of size selectivity and the nature of host−guest interactions. Taken together, the results presented in this work illustrate the structure−property relationship at the supramolecular level. They also demonstrate the feasibility of achieving well-defined porous and stable lanthanide-organic frameworks with coordinatively unsaturated metal sites. Currently, we are extending this work to larger spacer ligands, hoping to attain lanthanide-organic frameworks with Lewis-acidic lanthanide ions arrayed on the wall of large open channels. Such systems would be well suited for the study of size- and shape-selective catalysis of various important organic reactions known to be catalyzed by lanthanide Lewis acids.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

We have synthesized novel isostructural lanthanide coordination polymers of the formula [Ln2(PDA)3(H2O)]⋅2H2O. We have used [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]⋅2H2O representatively to investigate the porous behavior of such compounds. Both the guest and the coordinated water molecules can be removed from the open channels of [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]⋅2H2O, yielding [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)] and [Er2(PDA)3], respectively. Both of these porous phases maintain the framework and crystalline order found in the original compound [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]⋅2H2O, as shown by XRD analyses. The framework polymer [Er2(PDA)3] is highly robust, remaining stable up to 450 °C. [Er2(PDA)3] adsorbs CO2, but not Ar or N2, apparently because of size selectivity and the nature of host-guest interactions. Taken together, the results presented in this work illustrate the structure-property relationship at the supramolecular level. They also demonstrate the feasibility of achieving well-defined porous and stable lanthanide-organic frameworks with coordinatively unsaturated metal sites. Currently, we are extending this work to larger spacer ligands, hoping to attain lanthanide-organic frameworks with Lewis-acidic lanthanide ions arrayed on the wall of large open channels. Such systems would be well suited for the study of size- and shape-selective catalysis of various important organic reactions known to be catalyzed by lanthanide Lewis acids.

cln_elements.content: Synthesis of [Ln 2 (PDA) 3 (H 2 O)]·2H 2 O (Ln = La, Er). Identical procedures were employed to prepare the two compounds; that for the erbium compound is described here in detail. A mixture of Er(NO3)3·5H2O (0.353 g, 0.80 mmol) and H2PDA (0.095 g, 0.49 mmol) was placed in a Teflon-lined Parr bomb containing 10 mL of deionized water and 1 mL of ethanol. The bomb was sealed, heated at 170 °C for 3 days, and allowed to cool to room temperature. Pink crystals were isolated by decanting the supernatant, washed thoroughly with deionized water, ethanol, and acetone, and air-dried to give 0.124 g of product (78%). Main IR absorption bands (cm-1):  3422 (w, br), 1529 (s, br), 1396 (s), 1278 (m), 718 (m). Anal. Calcd for C30H30O15Er2 = [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]·2H2O:  C, 37.34; H, 3.13. Found:  C, 37.31; H, 3.00. The phase purity of the bulk products was checked by comparing its observed and simulated XRD patterns.
cln_elements.clean_text: Synthesis of [Ln  2  (PDA)  3  (H  2  O)]⋅2H  2  O (Ln = La, Er). Identical procedures were employed to prepare the two compounds; that for the erbium compound is described here in detail. A mixture of Er(NO3)3⋅5H2O (0.353 g, 0.80 mmol) and H2PDA (0.095 g, 0.49 mmol) was placed in a Teflon-lined Parr bomb containing 10 mL of deionized water and 1 mL of ethanol. The bomb was sealed, heated at 170 °C for 3 days, and allowed to cool to room temperature. Pink crystals were isolated by decanting the supernatant, washed thoroughly with deionized water, ethanol, and acetone, and air-dried to give 0.124 g of product (78%). Main IR absorption bands (cm-1): 3422 (w, br), 1529 (s, br), 1396 (s), 1278 (m), 718 (m). Anal. Calcd for C30H30O15Er2 = [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]⋅2H2O: C, 37.34; H, 3.13. Found: C, 37.31; H, 3.00. The phase purity of the bulk products was checked by comparing its observed and simulated XRD patterns.

cln_elements.content: Thermal Analyses. A TG analysis performed on a sample of [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]·2H2O showed continuous weight loss (5.47%) between 50 and 140 °C, which corresponded to the loss of three water molecules per formula unit (calcd 5.59%). No further weight loss was observed until it reached 450 °C, at which the decomposition of [Er2(PDA)3] occurred, as indicated by a significant weight loss (57.1%). No attempt was made to identify the products of decomposition. A TG analysis of [La2(PDA)3(H2O)]·2H2O gave similar results.
cln_elements.clean_text: Thermal Analyses. A TG analysis performed on a sample of [Er2(PDA)3(H2O)]⋅2H2O showed continuous weight loss (5.47%) between 50 and 140 °C, which corresponded to the loss of three water molecules per formula unit (calcd 5.59%). No further weight loss was observed until it reached 450 °C, at which the decomposition of [Er2(PDA)3] occurred, as indicated by a significant weight loss (57.1%). No attempt was made to identify the products of decomposition. A TG analysis of [La2(PDA)3(H2O)]⋅2H2O gave similar results.
